clinical_study.brief_title: Pilot Study of a Nerve Block Simulator for the Training in Axillary Blocks
clinical_study.official_title: Simulator Versus Cadaver Training to Perform Ultrasound-guided Axillary Nerve Bocks

lead_sponsor.agency: Fundación Universitaria de Ciencias de la Salud

clinical_study.source: Fundación Universitaria de Ciencias de la Salud

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether an ultrasound-guided nerve block simulator is effective for the training of the axillary block technique.

detailed_description.textblock: Ultrasound-guided nerve blocks are becoming the standard of care in patients requiring regional anesthesia. Cost-effective training is needed for the implementation of these techniques in the global anesthesia practice. Existing simulators are expensive and not available in low income countries. The investigators aimed to test an inexpensive simulator for the training in this technique.

primary_outcome.measure: Time to locate axillary nerve in a cadaver
primary_outcome.time_frame: At the end of the procedure, expected average of 30 seconds

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to identify axillary nerve in a cadaver
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the procedure, expected average of 15 seconds

arm_group.description: One training session with the simulator.
One training session with a cadaver.

intervention.description: Axillary nerve anatomy lecture plus training with the simulator.
Axillary nerve anatomy lecture plus training with the cadaver model.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Anesthesia residents
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous training in regional anesthesia techniques
